In this session we will:
• Understand the core ideas behind Dynamic Programming.
• Look at Python code so the ideas feel concrete.
• Discuss typical interview or exam-style questions.

blogArticle:
## Lesson 18: Dynamic Programming

In this lesson of *Programmer’s Picnic*, we explore **Dynamic Programming**. We introduce dynamic programming as optimized recursion with memoization or tabulation, focusing on patterns like knapsack and LIS.

### Why this topic matters

In competitive programming, interviews, and real projects, dynamic programming appear naturally. Being comfortable with this topic lets you:

- Model problems in a clean, structured way.
- Choose the right data structure or technique for constraints.
- Reason about time and space complexity so you do not over-engineer or under-engineer solutions.

### Core ideas

We cover the following ideas in this lesson:

1. Intuition and real-life analogies where possible.
2. Formal definitions and properties.
3. Python representations and idiomatic code.
4. Common pitfalls and how to avoid them.
5. Typical patterns in interview questions.

The best way to learn is to read the code, run it, and then modify small pieces to see what changes. Treat this lesson as a starting point, not the final word.
practiceProblems: Easy: A warm-up problem related to Dynamic Programming to check basic understanding.
Medium: A slightly more involved problem that forces you to apply the main idea of Dynamic Programming.
Hard: A challenging or interview-style problem that may combine Dynamic Programming with previous topics.
homework: HW1: Implement at least two variations of an example from this lesson on your own, without copy–paste, and push them to your GitHub repository.
HW2: Write a short note or blog post in your own words summarizing what you learned about Dynamic Programming.
HW3 (Optional): Pick a problem from an online judge (LeetCode / Codeforces / etc.) that uses this topic and solve it end-to-end.
